qas.question: What do philosophers do, in Whitehead's view?

answers.text: make metaphysical assumptions about how the universe works

qas.question: Assumptions of how the universe works are difficult to see precisely because of what?
What did Whitehead ask people to reimagine in order for philosophy to make progress?

answers.text: basic assumptions about how the universe works

qas.question: What did Whitehead regard as essential to good science and good philosophy?
What quotation of Whitehead's was noted by a student in 1927?

answers.text: "Every scientific man in order to preserve his reputation has to say he dislikes metaphysics. What he means is he dislikes having his metaphysics criticized."

qas.question: What was Whitehead's opinion of basic assumptions in metaphysics?

answers.text: such assumptions are not easily seen precisely because they remain unexamined and unquestioned

qas.question: What did Whitehead feel was necessary regarding basic assumptions in metaphysics?

answers.text: people need to continually re-imagine their basic assumptions about how the universe works if philosophy and science are to make any real progress

qas.question: What was Whitehead's opinion of metaphysical investigations?

answers.text: Whitehead regarded metaphysical investigations as essential to both good science and good philosophy

plausible_answers.text: Every scientific man in order to preserve his reputation has to say he dislikes metaphysics. What he means is he dislikes having his metaphysics criticized

qas.question: What quotation of Whitehead's was noted by a student in 1977?

plausible_answers.text: people need to continually re-imagine their basic assumptions about how the universe works

qas.question: What did Whitehead feel was necessary regarding complex assumptions in metaphysics?

plausible_answers.text: regarded metaphysical investigations as essential to both good science and good philosophy

qas.question: What was Whitehead's opinion of nonmetaphysical investigations?

context: Whitehead was unimpressed by this objection. In the notes of one his students for a 1927 class, Whitehead was quoted as saying: <a4_0>"<b8_0>Every scientific man in order to preserve his reputation has to say he dislikes metaphysics. What he means is he dislikes having his metaphysics criticized<b8_0/>."<a4_0/> In Whitehead's view, scientists and philosophers <a0_0>make metaphysical assumptions about how the universe works<a0_0/> all the time, but <a5_0>such assumptions are not easily seen precisely because <a1_0>they remain unexamined and unquestioned<a5_0/><a1_0/>. While Whitehead acknowledged that "philosophers can never hope finally to formulate these metaphysical first principles," he argued that <a6_0><b9_0>people need to continually re-imagine their <a2_0>basic assumptions about how the universe works<b9_0/><a2_0/> if philosophy and science are to make any real progress<a6_0/>, even if that progress remains permanently asymptotic. For this reason <a7_0>Whitehead <b10_0>regarded <a3_0>metaphysical investigations<a3_0/> as essential to both good science and good philosophy<b10_0/><a7_0/>.
